Expressions and Operators

　An expression is a collection of operators and operands, or a literal value.

　Usually, they can be written in scripts as follows:

    expression;

　Adding a semicolon after an expression like this evaluates (= executes) the expression on the spot, and the result of the expression is discarded.


Example:
    a = b;
    // Variable b is assigned to variable a by the operation of the = operator

    func();
    // func is called as a function by the operation of the ( ) operator, but the function's return value
    // is discarded

    1 + 3;
    // 1 and 3 are added by the operation of the + operator, but the result is discarded (in fact, this
    // expression is meaningless, so it is not even executed)

True and False

　Some operators handle true or false (logical values). If the result of the operation is 0, it is false; if it is non-zero, it is true.
　When truth/falsehood is queried for a string, an empty string is false. Otherwise, an attempt is made to convert it to a number; if successful, the resulting numerical value determines truth/falsehood; if it fails, it is false.

Operators

　Below, operators are explained in order from lowest to highest precedence.

if Operator

　The if operator if is an operator that evaluates the expression on the left only if the result of evaluating the expression on the right is true.

Example:
    a=b if b!=0; // Assign b to a if b is not 0

　The result of the operator cannot be obtained.

Sequential Operator

　The sequential operator , (comma) evaluates the expression on the left and then evaluates the expression on the right. It does nothing else. The overall result of the operator is the result of evaluating the expression on the right. If multiple commas are written in succession, they are evaluated in order starting from the left.

Example:
    c = (a=1, b=2); // a=1 and b=2 are evaluated, and 2 is assigned to c
    a=1, b=2, c=3; // Evaluated in the order of a=1, b=2, c=3

Assignment Operators

　There are the following assignment operators:

= <-> &= |= ^= -= += %= /= \= *= ||= &&= >>= <<= >>>=
　Among these, the = operator is a simple assignment operator that assigns the result of evaluating the right side to the left side. The overall value of the operator is the result of evaluating the expression on the right side.

Example:
    a = 0;  // Assign 0 to a
    a = b = c = 0; // Assign 0 to c, b, and a in that order

　The <-> operator performs a swap. First, the left side is evaluated, then the right side. After that, the result of evaluating the right side is assigned to the left side, and the result of evaluating the left side is assigned to the right side. The result of the operator cannot be obtained.
　At this point, the left and right expressions are each evaluated twice: once to get the value of the expression and once to assign to the expression. This specification may change in the future, so please do not write code that depends on the number of evaluations.

　All other operators take the form operator=. When written as A operator= B, it means A = A operator B. The overall value of the operator is the result of the operation.

Conditional Operator

　The conditional operator ? : is a ternary operator. When written in the form A ? B : C, it evaluates A; if true, it evaluates B and ignores C. If false, it evaluates C and ignores B. The overall value of the operator is the value of whichever side (B or C) was evaluated.

　The conditional operator can be used as an lvalue.

Example:
    a = b==0 ? c : b; // If b is 0, assign c to a; if b is not 0, assign b to a
    b==0 ? (a=c) : (a=b); // Same meaning as above
    (a ? b : c ) = d; // If a is true, assign d to b; if a is false, assign d to c (Example of use as an lvalue)

Logical OR Operator

　The logical OR operator || first evaluates the left side; if true, it ignores the right side, and the overall result of the operator is true. If the result of evaluating the left side is false, it evaluates the right side, and the truth/falsehood of that result becomes the overall result of the operator.

Logical AND Operator

　The logical AND operator && first evaluates the left side; if false, it ignores the right side, and the overall result of the operator is false. If the result of evaluating the left side is true, it evaluates the right side, and that result becomes the overall result of the operator.

Bitwise OR Operator

　The bitwise OR operator | performs a bitwise logical OR. The left and right sides are evaluated in order, and the result of the bitwise OR of those values as integers becomes the overall value of the operator.

Bitwise XOR Operator

　The bitwise XOR operator ^ performs a bitwise logical XOR. The left and right sides are evaluated in order, and the result of the bitwise XOR of those values as integers becomes the overall value of the operator.

Bitwise AND Operator

　The bitwise AND operator & performs a bitwise logical AND. The left and right sides are evaluated in order, and the result of the bitwise AND of those values as integers becomes the overall value of the operator.

Equality Operators

　== != === !== are types of equality operators.

== operator
The == operator evaluates the left side first, then the right side. If both match, the overall operator is true; if they don't match, it is false. If the types differ as a result of the operations on both sides, they are compared after being appropriately converted. For example, -1 == '-1' is true.
!= operator
The != operator is the logical inverse of the == operator.
=== operator
The === operator is called the identity comparison operator; it is the same as the == operator, but no type conversion is performed, and it is only true if the types also match.
!== operator
The !== operator is the logical inverse of the === operator.

Comparison Operators

　< > <= >= are types of comparison operators.

< operator
The < operator evaluates the left side first, then the right side. If the result of evaluating the left side is smaller than the result of evaluating the right side, it is true; otherwise, it is false.
> operator
The > operator evaluates the left side first, then the right side. If the result of evaluating the right side is smaller than the result of evaluating the left side, it is true; otherwise, it is false.
<= operator
The <= operator evaluates the left side first, then the right side. If the result of evaluating the left side is smaller than or equal to the result of evaluating the right side, it is true; otherwise, it is false.
>= operator
The >= operator evaluates the left side first, then the right side. If the result of evaluating the right side is smaller than or equal to the result of evaluating the left side, it is true; otherwise, it is false.

　If both things being compared are strings, the comparison is in wide character code order (usually UNICODE).

Bitwise Shift Operators

　>> << >>> are types of bitwise shift operators.

>> operator
The >> operator first evaluates the left side, then the right side. With the left result as an integer, the result of a signed bitwise shift to the right by the number of times specified by the right result is the overall result of the operator.
<< operator
The << operator first evaluates the left side, then the right side. With the left result as an integer, the result of a bitwise shift to the left by the number of times specified by the right result is the overall result of the operator.
>>> operator
The >>> operator is the same as the >> operator, but treats the result of evaluating the left side as an unsigned integer.

Addition and Subtraction Operators

　+ - are the addition and subtraction operators, respectively.

+ operator
The + operator evaluates the left side first, then the right side. If both results are numeric, numerical addition is performed and becomes the overall result of the operator. If either or both are strings, string addition is performed, and the overall result is a string with the right result concatenated after the left result. Numbers are converted to strings, and object types are converted to strings if possible.
- operator
The - operator evaluates the left side first, then the right side. After that, the right result is subtracted from the left result as numbers, and that becomes the overall value of the operator.

Multiplication, Division, and Remainder Operators

　% / \ * are the remainder, division, integer division, and multiplication operators, respectively.

% operator
The % operator evaluates the left side first, then the right side. After that, the remainder of dividing the left side by the right side becomes the overall value of the operator. Both values are treated as integers.
/ operator
The / operator evaluates the left side first, then the right side. After that, the result of dividing the left side by the right side becomes the overall value of the operator. Values are treated as real numbers.
\ operator
The \ operator performs division like the / operator, but values are treated as integers.
* operator
The * operator evaluates the left side first, then the right side. After that, the result of multiplying the left side by the right side becomes the overall value of the operator. Values are treated as real numbers.

Common Unary Operators

　All of the following are unary operators (with instanceof being an exception).

! operator
The prefix ! operator is the logical negation operator. The overall value of the operator is the inverse truth/falsehood of the result of evaluating the expression on the right.
~ operator
The ~ operator is the bitwise negation operator. Evaluates the expression on the right as an integer, and the result of performing bitwise negation (1→0, 0→1) becomes the overall value of the operator.
-- operator
The prefix -- operator is the prefix decrement operator. Subtracts 1 from the value on the right, and the value after subtraction becomes the overall value of the operator.
++ operator
The prefix ++ operator is the prefix increment operator. Adds 1 to the value on the right, and the value after addition becomes the overall value of the operator.
new operator
The new operator causes the function evaluation expression on the right to perform object creation instead of a function call.
invalidate operator
The invalidate operator evaluates the expression on the right and invalidates the resulting object. If the expression on the right evaluates to void, a string, a number, or an octet sequence, it does nothing. It also does nothing if the object is already invalidated. An exception occurs if null is specified.
isvalid operator
The isvalid operator evaluates the expression on the right or left; it becomes true if the resulting object is valid and false if invalid. It has the same meaning whether the operator is placed before or after the target. It always returns true if the target is void, a string, a number, or an octet sequence. An exception occurs if null is specified.
delete operator
The delete operator deletes a member of the object or a local variable specified on the right. Returns true if deletion is successful, false otherwise.
typeof operator
The typeof operator evaluates the expression on the right and returns one of the following strings depending on its type: void: "void", integer: "Integer", real number: "Real", object: "Object", string: "String", octet sequence: "Octet". However, if an object member is specified and the member does not exist, it becomes "undefined".
# operator
The # operator evaluates the expression on the right and returns the character code of the first character of the resulting string as the overall value of the operator.
$ operator
The $ operator evaluates the expression on the right and treats the result as a character code, returning the single character it represents as the overall value of the operator.
+ operator
The unary + operator evaluates the expression on the right. If it is a real number or integer, it does nothing. Otherwise, it attempts to convert it to a real or numeric value, and the result becomes the overall result of the operator. When attempting to convert a string to a number, if the conversion fails, it becomes 0 without raising an exception. If it is a real number representation including a decimal point, it is converted to a real number; otherwise, it is converted to an integer. If the string starts with 0x, 0b, or 0, it is interpreted as hexadecimal, binary, or octal, respectively.
- operator
The unary - operator evaluates the expression on the right and returns the negative of that numeric result as the overall result of the operator.
& operator
The unary & operator changes access to an object member written on the right to access the property object itself, bypassing the property handler. For example, in propobj = &obj.prop;, the property handler for member property prop of obj is not triggered, and a reference to the property object itself of member property prop is assigned to propobj. Behavior is undefined if the right side is not a property access.
* operator
The unary * operator executes the property handler of the object written on the right. An expression representing a property object must be written on the right. For example, *propobj = 1; calls the setter handler of the property object propobj and assigns 1.
instanceof operator
The instanceof operator evaluates the left side first, then the right side. On the right, write something that results in a string (the class name); it returns true if the left side is an instance of that class, false otherwise.

Function Calls, Brackets, Postfix Increment/Decrement, etc.

( ) operator
The ( ) operator changes the precedence of operations. Alternatively, it performs a function call.
[ ] operator
The [ ] operator is an indirect member selection operator. If written as A [ B ], A is evaluated first, then B. Treating B as a string, it looks for that member name in A, and the overall operator acts as access to that member. When used as an lvalue, it also has the effect of creating member B within the object if it doesn't already exist.
. operator
The . operator is a direct member selection operator. If written as A.B, A is evaluated. It looks for B within A, and the overall operator acts as access to that member. When used as an lvalue, it also has the effect of creating member B within the object if it doesn't already exist.
If the left side of the . operator is omitted, it refers to a member in the global object if outside a with statement, or a member of the object indicated by that with if inside a with statement.
++ operator
The postfix ++ operator is the postfix increment operator. Adds 1 to the value on the left, and the overall value of the operator is the value on the left before addition.
-- operator
The postfix -- operator is the postfix decrement operator. Subtracts 1 from the value on the left, and the overall value of the operator is the value on the left before subtraction.
! operator
The postfix ! operator is the expression evaluation operator. Treats the result of evaluating the left side as a string and interprets it as an expression string. The result is the outcome of interpreting and evaluating that expression string. The expression runs on the this context (the this at the location where this operator is used).
incontextof operator
The incontextof operator evaluates the left side first, then the right side. Treating the result of evaluating the left side as an object, the result of the entire operation is that object with its context part replaced by the result of evaluating the right side.
int operator
The int operator evaluates the expression on the right, and the result of converting it to an integer type becomes the overall result of the operator. It can also be written as (int) in a C-style cast.
real operator
The real operator evaluates the expression on the right, and the result of converting it to a real number type becomes the overall result of the operator. It can also be written as (real) in a C-style cast.
string operator
The string operator evaluates the expression on the right, and the result of converting it to a string type becomes the overall result of the operator. It can also be written as (string) in a C-style cast.
